Athari Comments on the Tahawi Creed by Imams of the Salafi Call
Muhammad bin Abdul Aziz bin Mani', may Allah have mercy on him (1298 - 1385 AH)
Abdul Aziz bin Abdullah bin Baz, may Allah have mercy on him (1330 AH - 1420 AH)
Muhammad Nasir al-Din al-Albani, may Allah have mercy on him (1332 AH - 1420 AH)
Compiled and Prepared by / Ahmed bin Yahya al-Zahrani

Introduction
In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful.
Indeed, all praise is due to Allah. We praise Him, we seek His help, and we seek His forgiveness. We seek refuge in Allah from the evil of our own souls and from our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is no one to misguide him, and whomever He misguides, there is no guide for him. I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, without partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger.
{O you who believe! Fear Allah as He should be feared, and die not except in a state of Islam (as Muslims).} 
{O mankind! Be dutiful to your Lord, Who created you from a single person (Adam), and from him (Adam) He created his wife [Hawwa (Eve)], and from them both He created many men and women; and fear Allah through Whom you demand (your mutual rights), and (do not cut the relations of) the wombs (kinship). Indeed Allah is ever an All-Watcher over you.}
{O you who believe! Keep your duty to Allah and fear Him, and speak (always) the truth. He will direct you to do righteous good deeds and will forgive you your sins. And whosoever obeys Allah and His Messenger, he has indeed achieved a great achievement.}
To proceed:
Indeed, the most truthful speech is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. The worst of affairs are newly invented matters, and every newly invented matter is a heresy (Bid'ah), and every heresy is a misguidance, and every misguidance is in the Fire.
After that:
He (the Prophet), may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: ((If you deal in 'Eeenah (a type of usury), and hold onto the tails of cows, and are content with agriculture, and abandon Jihad, Allah will inflict upon you a humiliation that He will not remove until you return to your religion)) (1).

So there is no glory and no victory for the Muslims, indeed, no revival, except by returning to their religion and adhering to their correct Creed and its upright Methodology. For they (1) are the foundation of all success and prosperity. The early Muslims were not victorious except by their adherence to their Creed and Methodology, both scientifically and practically (2). What we see today of weakness, division, and partisanship between – and within – the ranks of Muslims, and the ganging up of enemies against them, is due to their neglect of this foundation.
The scholars of Islam realized this danger, so they rose with a strong and sincere uprising, authoring books to clarify the Creed – and its importance, the obligation of adhering to it, and the warning against contradicting it. Among those unique scholars was Abu Ja'far Ahmad bin Muhammad al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him (3). He authored a text known as 'The Tahawi Creed' (Al-Aqidah Al-Tahawiyyah), which met with wide acceptance among the masses of Muslims, predecessors and successors. Scholars engaged with it through explanation, commentary, and critique, and that is only due to its importance and the great standing of its author.

Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.
The Scholar, the Proof of Islam, Abu Ja'far al-Warraq al-Tahawi - in Egypt, may Allah have mercy on him, said:
This is a mention of the clarification of the creed of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah according to the school (Madhab) (1) of the jurists of the religion: Abu (2) Hanifa al-Nu'man bin Thabit al-Kufi, and Abu (3)

…. His saying "according to the school of the jurists of the religion etc.": Know that what the author, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned in this creed is not specific only to these mentioned Imams. Rather, the creed of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah from the first ones and the last ones is one; because they hold fast to the Book and the Sunnah. Whoever opposes them in their belief becomes a deviant innovator and is not excused by his independent reasoning (Ijtihad); because excuse is accepted in Ijtihad regarding the branches of rulings, not in the fundamentals of religion. Religious beliefs do not allow for a multiplicity of schools; rather, the correct way is the school of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, and whatever else is false, so take note. (M)

…. His saying (We say regarding the Oneness of Allah... etc.)
…. Know that Tawhid (Monotheism), with which Allah sent the Messengers and revealed the Books, is divided into three categories according to the induction of texts from the Book and the Sunnah and according to the reality of the accountable people:
…. The First Category: Tawhid al-Rububiyyah (Oneness of Lordship). This is unifying Allah in His actions, Glory be to Him. It is the belief that He is the Creator, the Provider, the Planner of the affairs of His creation, the Disposer of their matters in this world and the Hereafter; He has no partner in that. As the Almighty said: {Allah is the Creator of all things} [Az-Zumar: 62]. And He said: {Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and the earth in six days and then established Himself above the Throne, arranging the matter} [Yunus: 3]. This type was acknowledged by the polytheists who worshipped idols, even if most of them denied the Resurrection, and it did not enter them into Islam due to their associating partners with Allah in worship and worshipping idols and statues along with Him, Glory be to Him, and their lack of belief in the Messenger Muhammad, may peace and blessings be upon him and his family.
 The Second Category: Tawhid al-Ibadah (Oneness of Worship), also called Tawhid al-Uluhiyyah. This is worship. This category is what the polytheists denied, as Allah mentioned about them: {And they wonder that there has come to them a warner from among themselves. And the disbelievers say, "This is a magician and a liar. Has he made the gods [only] one God? Indeed, this is a curious thing."} [Sad: 4-5], and similar verses are many. This category implies making worship purely for Allah alone and believing that He is the One deserving of it and that the worship of anyone else is false. This is the meaning of 'La ilaha illa Allah' (There is no god but Allah), for its meaning is there is no one worshipped
…. rightfully except Allah, as Allah Almighty said: {That is because Allah is the Truth, and that what they call upon other than Him is falsehood} [Al-Hajj: 62].
 The Third Category: Tawhid al-Asma' wa al-Sifat (Oneness of Names and Attributes): It is believing in everything mentioned in the Noble Book of Allah and in the Authentic Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, may peace and blessings be upon him and his family, regarding the Names of Allah and His Attributes, and affirming them for Allah, Glory be to Him, in a manner that befits Him, without distortion (Tahrif), negation (Ta'til), asking 'how' (Takyif), or likening Him to creation (Tamthil). As Allah Glory be to Him said: {Say, "He is Allah, [who is] One, Allah, the Eternal Refuge. He neither begets nor is born, Nor is there to Him any equivalent."} [Surah Al-Ikhlas]. And He said: {There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing.} [Ash-Shura: 11]. And He said: {And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them.} [Al-A'raf: 180]. And He said in Surah An-Nahl: {And to Allah belongs the highest attribute. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.} [An-Nahl: 60]. The verses in this meaning are many. The 'highest attribute' is the supreme description which has no deficiency. This is the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah from the companions of the Messenger, may peace and blessings be upon him and his family, and those who follow them in goodness. They pass the verses of Attributes and their hadiths as they came, affirming their meanings for Allah, Glory be to Him—an affirmation free from likening (Tamthil)—and exalting Allah, Glory be to Him, from resembling His creation—an exaltation free from negation (Ta'til). With what they said, the evidences from the Book and Sunnah unite, and the proof is established against those who oppose them. They are the ones mentioned in His saying: {And the first forerunners [in the faith] among the Muhajireen and the Ansar and those who followed them with good conduct - Allah is pleased with them and they are pleased with Him, and He has prepared for them gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. That is the great attainment.} [At-Tawbah: 100]. May Allah make us among them by His grace and generosity. And Allah is the One sought for help. (Z)

…. Denying a partner for Allah Almighty is not complete except by denying three types of Shirk (Polytheism):

First: Shirk in Lordship (Rububiyyah), which is believing that there is another creator with Allah – Glory be to Him – as is the belief of the Magians (Zoroastrians) who say that there is a creator for evil other than Allah Glory be to Him.  Second: Shirk in Divinity or Worship (Uluhiyyah/Ubudiyyah), which is worshipping others along with Allah, such as prophets and righteous people, like seeking aid from them and calling upon them in hardships and the like. Unfortunately, this is common in this Ummah, and the greatest burden of it is borne by those Sheikhs who support this type of Shirk under the name of Tawassul (Intercession) ((They name it by other than its name))!.
 Third: Shirk in Attributes (Sifat), which is describing some of His creation with some attributes specific to Him, the Mighty and Majestic, such as knowledge of the Unseen, for example. This type is widespread among many Sufis and those influenced by them, such as the saying of some of them in praise of the Prophet, peace be upon him:
...... ((For from your generosity is the world and its co-wife (Hereafter) 
…. And from your sciences is the knowledge of the Tablet and the Pen!))
From here came the misguidance of some impostors who claim that they see the Messenger - peace be upon him - today while awake and ask him about what is hidden from them of the inner selves of those they mix with, and they want to appoint them in some of their affairs. Yet the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, would not know such things during his lifetime {And if I knew the unseen, I could have acquired much good, and no evil would have touched me.} [Al-A'raf: 188], so how could he know that after his death and transfer to the Supreme Companion?!
 Whoever denies these three types of Shirk from Allah has unified Him; thus he has unified Him in His Essence, His Worship, and His Attributes. He is the Monotheist (Muwahhid) covered by all virtues specific to Monotheists. Whoever violates any part of it, to him is directed the likes of His saying Almighty: {If you should associate [anything] with Allah, your work would surely become worthless, and you would surely be among the losers.} [Az-Zumar: 65]. So memorize this, for it is the most important thing in Creed. No wonder the author, may Allah have mercy on him, began with it. Whoever wants detail should refer to the explanation of this book and the books of the Sheikhs of Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, Ibn al-Qayyim, Ibn Abdul Wahhab, and others who followed their path and pursued their way. {Our Lord, forgive us and our brothers who preceded us in faith} [Al-Hashr: 10]. (N)

foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. This is a principle from the principles of Tawhid, which is that there is nothing like Allah Almighty, neither in His Essence, nor in His Attributes, nor in His Actions. However, the innovators and interpreters have taken it as a basis for denying many attributes of Allah
…. Blessed and Exalted. Whenever their hearts become constricted about believing in an attribute of His, the Mighty and Majestic, they unleash upon it the pickaxes of interpretation and demolition, so they deny it, using as evidence His saying: {There is nothing like Him}, ignoring the rest of the verse: {and He is the Hearing, the Seeing} [Ash-Shura: 11]. For it combined transcendence (Tanzih) and affirmation (Ithbat). So whoever wants safety in his creed must declare Allah Almighty transcendent above resembling created things (events), without interpretation or negation, and must affirm for Him, the Mighty and Majestic, all attributes He affirmed for Himself in His Book or the Hadith of His Prophet without likening Him (to creation). This is the school of the Salaf, and upon it is the author, may Allah have mercy on him, following Abu Hanifa and the rest of the Imams, as you see detailed in the Explanation. {So follow their guidance.} [Al-An'am: 90]. (N)
2. 
…. a) His saying ((Ancient/Qadim)): He, Glory be to Him, is described with Pre-existence (*Qidam*) in the sense that He is informed about by that, as Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned in Al-Bada'i'; and the door of informing is wider than the door of restricted Attributes (*Tawqifiyyah*). The scholars did not mention the word *Al-Qadim* among the Beautiful Names, but they inform about Him, Glory be to Him, with it. He said in Al-Nuniyyah:
…. And He is the Ancient (*Al-Qadim*), He has never ceased in His attributes
…. Unique, indeed, everlasting in benevolence. (M)
 b) His saying (Ancient without beginning): This wording did not appear in the Beautiful Names of Allah as the Commentator, may Allah have mercy on him, and others pointed out. Rather, many theologians (Kalam scholars) mentioned it to prove His existence before everything. The Names of Allah are restricted (*Tawqifiyyah*); it is not permissible to affirm any of them except by text from the Noble Book or the Authentic Sunnah, and it is not permissible to affirm any of them by opinion, as stated by the Imams of the Righteous Salaf. The word *Al-Qadim* does not indicate the meaning intended by the theologians because in Arabic it means 'that which precedes others', even if it was preceded by non-existence, as in His saying Almighty: {until it returns like the old (*Al-Qadim*) date stalk} [Ya-Sin: 39]. It only indicates the true meaning with the addition mentioned by the author, which is his saying: (Ancient *without beginning*). However, it should not be counted among Allah's Beautiful Names due to its lack of textual proof, and His Name, Glory be to Him, 'Al-Awwal' (The First) suffices for it, as the Mighty and Majestic said: {He is the First and the Last} [Al-Hadid: 3]. And Allah is the Guardian of success. (Z)
 c) Know that (Al-Qadim) is not among the Names of Allah Almighty. It is from the usage of the theologians. *Al-Qadim* in the language of the Arabs in which the Quran was revealed means 'the one preceding others'. It is said: 'This is *qadim*' for old, and 'this is *jadid*' for new. They did not use this name except for what precedes others, not for what was not preceded by non-existence, as He said: {until it returns like the old (*Al-Qadim*) date stalk} [Ya-Sin: 39]. The old date stalk: that which remains until the existence of the second date stalk; so if the new one exists, the first is called old (*qadim*), even if it was preceded by another, as verified by Sheikh al-Islam in ((Majmoo' al-Fatawa)) (1/245) and the Commentator in his ((Explanation)). However, Sheikh Ibn Mani' benefitted us here in what he quoted from Ibn al-Qayyim in ((Al-Bada'i')) that it is permissible to describe Him, Glory be to Him, with Pre-existence (*Qidam*) in the sense that He is informed about by that, and the door of news is wider than the door of restricted Attributes. I say: Perhaps this is the reason Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah used this description sometimes, as will come in what I comment on paragraph (45). (N)

However, he used a generalized phrase needing detailing to remove ambiguity. By "limits" (*Hudud*) he means those known to humans; for He, Glory be to Him, His limits are known only to Him, Glory be to Him, because creation does not encompass Him in knowledge, as the Mighty and Majestic said in Surah Taha: {He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them, but they do not encompass it in knowledge.} [Taha: 110]. Whoever among the Salaf spoke of affirming a limit (*Hadd*) regarding *Istiwa* (Rising) or otherwise, meant a limit known to Allah Glory be to Him and not known to the servants. As for (ends, pillars, limbs, tools), his intention, may Allah have mercy on him, is declaring Him transcendent above resembling creatures in His wisdom and His essential attributes like Face, Hand, Foot, and similar things. He, Glory be to Him, is described with that, but His attributes are not like the attributes of creation, and none knows their modality except Him, Glory be to Him. The people of innovation use such terms to deny Attributes using words other than what Allah spoke and affirmed for Himself, so they are not exposed and so the people of truth do not condemn them. The author Al-Tahawi, may Allah have mercy on him, did not intend this objective because he is from Ahl al-Sunnah who affirm Allah's attributes. His speech in this Creed explains itself and verifies itself, and its ambiguous parts are interpreted by its clear parts. Likewise his saying (the six directions do not encompass Him like all originated things); his intent is the six *created* directions, and his intent is not to deny Allah's Highness (*Uluww*) and His Rising (*Istiwa*) over His Throne, because that is not included in the six directions; rather He is above the world and encompassing it. Allah has created His servants with the innate nature (*Fitrah*) to believe in His Highness, Glory be to Him, and that He is in the direction of Above. Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah from the Companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, and those who follow them in goodness, have agreed on that. The evidences from the Book and the Authentic Mutawatir Sunnah all indicate that He is in the Highness (*Uluww*), Glory be to Him. So pay attention to this great matter, O noble reader, and know that it is the Truth and whatever else is false. And Allah is the Guardian of success. (Z)

text:

foot_note:

He decreed His creation then rose over His Throne
And no place in the earth is devoid of His knowledge
As for the meaning of *Istiwa* in the language of the Arabs in which the Quran was revealed, it is Highness (*Uluww*), Elevation (*Irtifa'*), Settling (*Istiqrar*), and Ascent (*Su'ud*), as Ibn al-Qayyim mentioned saying:
And they have four expressions for it
Which have been achieved by the stabbing knight
Among them is *Istaqarra* (settled), and *Ala* (became high)
And likewise *Irtafa'a* (rose), in which there is no denial
And likewise *Sa'ida* (ascended), which is the fourth
And Abu Ubaidah, owner of Al-Shayban
Chooses this saying in his explanation
More knowledgeable than the Jahmi regarding the Quran
And the Ash'ari says the explanation of *Istawa* is
In reality *Istawla* (conquered), out of falsehood
The Nun of the Jews and the Lam of the Jahmi
Are two additions in the Revelation of the Lord of the Throne (M)
 b) Know that the Throne is a very great creation as indicated by Quranic verses and Prophetic Hadiths. Therefore, the Exalted attributed it to Himself in His saying: {Owner of the Throne}, and there are other verses you will find in ((The Explanation)). Linguistically it is the bed of the King. Among its descriptions in the Quran: {and eight will bear the Throne of your Lord above them, that Day} [Al-Haqqah: 17], and that it is upon water. In the Sunnah, the distance between the earlobe and shoulder of one of the Throne bearers is a journey of seven hundred years, and it has pillars, and it is the roof of Jannat al-Firdaus. This came in authentic Hadiths mentioned in ((The Explanation)). All of this invalidates the interpretation of the Throne as being an expression for Dominion and expanse of Authority!.
 As for the Chair (*Kursi*), regarding it is His saying: {His Chair extends over the heavens and the earth} [Al-Baqarah: 255]. The Chair is what is before the Throne. It is authentically reported from Ibn Abbas as his own statement (Mawquf): ((The Chair is the place of the two Feet, and the Throne cannot be estimated in measure except by Allah Almighty)). It is referenced in my book ((Mukhtasar al-Uluww by Al-Dhahabi)) may Allah facilitate its printing (1). Nothing authentic raised to the Prophet (Marfu') is established regarding it except his saying, peace be upon him: ((The seven heavens in relation to the Chair are like a ring thrown in a desert land, and the superiority of the Throne over the Chair is like the superiority of that desert over that ring)). This also invalidates interpreting the Chair as Knowledge. This interpretation from Ibn Abbas is not authentic as I clarified in ((Al-Sahihah)) (109). (N)

text: 50- And He is independent of the Throne and what is below it (1).
foot_note:

book_title: Athari Comments on the Tahawi Creed by Imams of the Salafi Call
text:
51- Encompassing everything and Above it (1), and He has rendered His creation incapable of encompassing. 

[Affirmation of Speech for Allah Almighty]
52- And we say: Allah took Abraham as a close friend (*Khalil*), and Allah spoke to Moses directly (*Taklima*), believing, confirming, and submitting.

[Belief in Angels, Prophets, and Revealed Books]
53- And we believe in the Angels, the Prophets, and the Books sent down upon the Messengers, and we bear witness that they were upon the clear Truth.
54- And we call the people of our Qiblah Muslims, Believers, as long as they acknowledge what the Prophet, peace be upon him, brought, and believe him in everything he said and informed of (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. I say: The copies differed regarding this word (*wa fawqahu* - and above it). In the Commentator's copy it is as you see, and likewise in manuscripts (A, B) and Sheikh Ibn Mani's print. In manuscript (C) and print (Kh): (*fawqahu*) without the conjunction Waw. Manuscript (Gh) deviated, containing (*wa bima fawqahu* - and what is above it)! There is no doubt about its irregularity and the one before it, in narration and meaning. As for narration, because it contradicts most copies. As for meaning, the Commentator explained it by saying (p. 281): ((The first version is the correct one)), meaning: He Almighty encompasses everything and is above everything. The meaning of the second is that He encompasses everything *above* the Throne. This - and Allah knows best - was either dropped by some scribes inadvertently and then people copied from that copy, or some deviant distorters dropped it intentionally for corruption and to deny the attribute of Highness (*Fawqiyyah*)! Otherwise, proof has established that the Throne is above creatures, and there is nothing of creatures above it. So there remains no meaning for saying: ((Encompassing)) - in the sense of: encompassing everything above the Throne - in this case, since there are no creatures above the Throne to encompass. Thus, the affirmation of the Waw is determined, and the meaning is: He, Glory be to Him, encompasses everything and is *Above* everything)). (N)
2. 
…. a) Mere belief and acknowledgment are not sufficient for the Islam and Iman commanded by Allah and His Messenger. The Islam and Iman upon which salvation revolves are those mentioned in the famous Hadith of Gabriel, peace be upon him, which includes belief, acknowledgment, and action. (M)
 b) The Commentator said: The Sheikh, may Allah have mercy on him, indicates that Islam and Iman are one, and that a Muslim does not exit Islam by committing a sin unless he deems it lawful. The meaning of his saying: ((People of our Qiblah)) is those who claim Islam and face the Kaaba, even if they are people of desires (innovation) or people of sin, as long as they do not deny anything the Messenger, peace be upon him, brought. (N)

book_title: Athari Comments on the Tahawi Creed by Imams of the Salafi Call
text:
[Prohibition of delving into Allah's Essence and disputing in Allah's Religion and His Quran]
55- We do not delve into (the essence of) Allah, nor do we dispute regarding the religion of Allah.
56- We do not argue about the Quran, and we bear witness that it is the Word of the Lord of the Worlds (1)
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. I say: One of the greatest tribulations that afflicted some Islamic sects due to theological rhetoric (*Ilm al-Kalam*) is that it deviated them from believing that the Holy Quran is the Word of the Lord of the Worlds in reality (*Haqiqah*), not metaphorically (*Majaz*). As for the Mu'tazilah who say it is created, their matter is clear and exposed. But there is a group that attributes itself to the Sunnah and refutes this saying of the Mu'tazilah and other things in which they deviated from Islam, namely the Ash'aris and Maturidis. In reality, they agree with the Mu'tazilah in saying the Quran is created and that it is not the saying of the Lord of the Worlds, except that they do not declare that openly. They hide behind their interpretation of Divine Speech as ancient inner speech (*Kalam Nafsi Qadim*) not heard by any angel or messenger, and that He Almighty does not speak if He wills, but is speaking since eternity. I saw an important research by Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, invalidating this interpretation of theirs. He said after affirming the pre-existence of Speech: ((Speech is an attribute of perfection; one who speaks is more perfect than one who does not, just as one who knows and is capable is more perfect than one who does not know or is not capable. One who speaks by his will and ability is more perfect than one who does not speak by his will and ability, and more perfect than one who speaks without his will and ability, if that is conceivable. It can be decided based on the principles of the Salaf by saying: Either He is capable of speech or not capable. If He is not =
…. capable, He is mute (*Akhras*). If He is capable but does not speak, He is silent (*Sakit*). As for the Kullabiyyah (followed by Ash'aris in this issue), Speech according to them is not subject to ability (*Maqdur*). So they cannot argue with this. It is said: This indicated the pre-existence of Speech, but does it imply the pre-existence of a specific speech without His ability and will? Or does it imply that He has never ceased speaking by His will and ability? The first: The saying of the Kullabiyyah. The second: The saying of the Salaf, the Imams, and Ahl al-Hadith wal-Sunnah. It is said: It implies the second, not the first, because affirming speech subsisting in the essence of the speaker without his will and ability is neither rational nor known. Judgment on a thing is a branch of conceptualizing it. It is said to the arguer: Neither you nor any rational person can conceive of speech subsisting in the essence of the speaker without his will and ability, so how do you affirm by rational evidence something irrational? Also, your saying: ((If He were not described with speech, He would be described with muteness and silence)) is only intelligible regarding speech with letters and sounds; if a living being lacks them, he is not a speaker. So either he is capable of speech and does not speak, which is the silent one, or he is not capable of it, which is the mute one. As for what they claim of Inner Speech (*Kalam Nafsi*), that is not intelligible, that whoever is devoid of it is silent or mute. So assuming its existence does not indicate that one devoid of it must be silent or mute. Also, the ancient psychological speech you affirmed, you did not establish what it is? Nay, you did not even conceive it! Affirming a thing branches from conceiving it. So whoever does not conceive what he affirms, how is it permissible for him to affirm it? That is why Abu Sa'id Ibn Kullab - the head of this sect (meaning Ash'aris) and its Imam in this issue - does not mention in explaining it anything intelligible. Rather he says: It is a meaning contradicting silence and muteness! Silence and muteness are only conceived if speech is conceived. The silent is one silent from speech, and the mute is one incapable of it, or who has a defect in the place of pronunciation preventing him from speech. Thus, the silent and mute are not known until speech is known, and speech is not known until the silent and mute are known. So it became clear that they did not conceive what they said nor established it. Rather, in speech, they resemble the Christians regarding the 'Word' (*Kalimah*) and what they said regarding the 'Hypostases' (*Aqanim*), 'Trinity', and 'Union'. For they say what they do not conceive nor clarify. The Messengers, peace be upon them, if they inform of something we do not conceive, it is obligatory to believe them. =
…. As for what is affirmed by reason, the one saying it must conceive it, otherwise he has spoken without knowledge. The Christians speak without knowledge; so their speech was contradictory and no rational saying resulted for them. Likewise, whoever speaks about Allah's Speech without knowledge, his speech is contradictory, and no intelligible saying results for him. That is why among the things denounced upon these people is that they argued for the foundation of their religion and knowing the reality of speech - Allah's speech and all creation's speech - with the saying of a Christian poet called Al-Akhtal:
Indeed, speech is in the heart, and only
......The tongue was made an indicator of the heart
A group said this is not his poetry. Assuming it is his poetry, rational realities, or the named 'speech' which all humans speak, reference is not made therein to the saying of a thousand virtuous poets, let alone a Christian poet named Al-Akhtal
….)) End summarized from ((Majmoo' al-Fatawa)) (6/294-297). (N)

It is the Word of Allah Almighty, nothing of the speech of creatures equals it. We do not say it is created (1), and we do not oppose the community (*Jama'ah*) of Muslims.
foot_note:

…. Know that the most famous of those saying the Quran is created are two sects: One is the Mu'tazilah, for they say: The Quran brought by Gabriel is the Word of Allah in reality but it is created. In this is a denial of the Message, because the Messenger only conveys the speech of the Sender. Ahl al-Sunnah obligated them with this. Ibn al-Qayyim said in Al-Nuniyyah:
If the attribute of Speech is negated
Likewise Sending is negated without distinction
For the message of the sent one is conveying the speech
Of the Sender, the Caller, without decrease
To the end of what he mentioned of great verses to be held onto with molars. It is most amazing that a scholar from the followers of Kullabiyyah discusses such researches, and if the Jahmiyyah and Mu'tazilah are mentioned, he says =

text:
[Not declaring People of Qiblah Disbelievers for Sins]
57- We do not declare anyone of the people of the Qiblah a disbeliever (*Kafir*) due to a sin, as long as he does not deem it lawful (*Yastahilluhu*) (1).
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. a) His saying 'We do not declare anyone of the people of the Qiblah... etc.': The intent by People of the Qiblah is those who unify Allah in His worship, are sincere to Him in dealing, act upon the meaning of the word of Tawhid outwardly and inwardly, believe the Messenger of Allah in all he informed, comply with his command, and do not commit what nullifies 'La ilaha illa Allah'. To this meaning the Author pointed previously saying: 'And we call the people of our Qiblah Muslims, Believers, as long as they acknowledge what the Prophet brought... etc.' because we believe the intent is complete Faith comprising belief, acknowledgment, and action. The Sheikh's intention, may Allah have mercy on him, with this speech is to refute the Khawarij who say one becomes a disbeliever by every sin. (M)
 b) His saying (We do not declare anyone of the people of the Qiblah a disbeliever due to a sin as long as he does not deem it lawful): He means, may Allah have mercy on him, that Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah do not declare the monotheist Muslim who believes in Allah and the Last Day a disbeliever due to a sin he commits, like adultery, drinking alcohol, usury, disobedience to parents, and the like, as long as he does not deem that lawful. If he deems it lawful, he disbelieves because he thereby denies Allah and His Messenger and exits His religion. But if he does not deem it lawful, he does not disbelieve according to Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah; rather he is weak in faith and has the ruling of the sins he committed regarding being labeled a sinner (*Fasiq*) and establishing penalties (*Hudud*) and so on as came in the purified Sharia. This is the saying of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah, contrary to the Khawarij, Mu'tazilah, and those who tread their false path. For the Khawarij declare disbelief for sins, and the Mu'tazilah place him in a station between two stations (neither believer nor disbeliever) in this world, but in the Hereafter they agree with the Khawarij that he is eternally in the Fire. The saying of both sects is false by the Book, Sunnah, and consensus of the predecessors of the Ummah. Their matter confused some people due to lack of knowledge, but their matter is praise be to Allah clear to the people of truth as we explained. And Allah is the Guardian of success. (Z)
 c) Meaning heart-felt doctrinal deeming of lawfulness (*Istihlal Itiqadi*); otherwise, every sinner deems his sin lawful practically, i.e., commits it. Therefore, one must differentiate between the one who deems it lawful doctrinally - he is a disbeliever by consensus - and the one who deems it lawful practically not doctrinally - he is a sinner deserving the punishment befitting him unless Allah forgives him, then his faith saves him. Contrary to the Khawarij and Mu'tazilah who judge him to be eternally in the Fire even if they differ in naming him Disbeliever or =
…. Hypocrite. A new shoot (*Nabitah*) has sprouted following these (Khawarij) in declaring the masses of Muslims, leaders and subjects, disbelievers without exception. I met groups of them in Syria, Mecca, and elsewhere. They have doubts like the doubts of the Khawarij, such as texts saying 'Whoever does such has disbelieved'. The Commentator, may Allah have mercy on him, cited a group of these here, and quoted Ahl al-Sunnah - who say Faith is speech and action, increasing and decreasing - that the sin, whatever it is, is practical disbelief (*Kufr Amali*) not doctrinal (*Itiqadi*), and that Disbelief to them is of levels: Disbelief less than Disbelief (*Kufr duna Kufr*), just like Faith. Then he struck an important example often missed by the referred new shoot. He said, may Allah have mercy on him (p. 323): Here is a matter that must be noticed, which is that Ruling by other than what Allah revealed may be Disbelief transferring from the Millah (Major Kufr), and may be a sin: major or minor, and be disbelief: either metaphorically, or minor disbelief, according to the two mentioned views. That depends on the state of the ruler. If he believes that ruling by what Allah revealed is not obligatory, and that he has a choice in it, or disdains it while certain it is Allah's ruling: this is Major Disbelief. If he believes the obligation of ruling by what Allah revealed and knows it in this incident, but turns away from it while acknowledging he deserves punishment, this is a sinner and is called a disbeliever in a metaphorical sense, or minor disbelief. If he was ignorant of Allah's ruling in it while expending his effort and capacity to know the ruling and erred, this is a mistaken one (*Mukhti'*) who has a reward for his Ijtihad, and his error is forgiven. (N)

book_title: Athari Comments on the Tahawi Creed by Imams of the Salafi Call
text:
[Refutation of the Murji'ah]
58- And we do not say (1) that a sin does not harm faith for the one who commits it (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. His saying: 'And we do not say that a sin does not harm faith... etc.' He intends by this speech to refute the Murji'ah who say a sin does not harm with faith just as obedience does not benefit with disbelief. These are at one extreme and the Khawarij at another; for they (Khawarij) say the Muslim disbelieves by every sin or every major sin. Likewise the Mu'tazilah who say his entire faith is annulled by a major sin so nothing of faith remains with him, but the Khawarij say he exits faith and enters disbelief, while the Mu'tazilah say he exits faith and does not enter disbelief. This erroneous saying is the 'Station between two stations' which is the specific school of the Mu'tazilah. By saying he exits faith, they necessitated his eternal abode in the Fire. (Caution) I used to read in books of sects and people's differences in beliefs and find the extremism of Mu'tazilah in their doctrines, then return to biographical books and search for the biographies of their senior Sheikhs, and find therein the objectionable strange matter of playing with religion and violating its sanctities. It became confirmed to me that this is =
…. from the bad omen of their doctrines and the corruption of their sect. Whoever reads the biography of Al-Nazzam, Abu al-Hudhayl al-Allaf, and the dissolute Al-Jahiz knows that. We ask Allah for safety. (M)
2. 
…. That is because it is from the saying of the Murji'ah leading to belying the verses of threat and its hadiths narrated regarding the sinners of this Ummah, and that groups of them enter the Fire, then exit from it by Intercession or otherwise. (N)

text: 59- We hope for the good-doers among the believers that He pardons them and enters them into Paradise by His mercy, but we are not secure over them, nor do we testify for them of Paradise (1).
foot_note:
1. (1) a) His saying 'nor do we testify for them of Paradise': Know that what Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah are upon is that they do not testify for anyone who died of the Muslims with Paradise or Fire except whom the Messenger of Allah testified for and informed about. However, they hope for the good-doer and fear for the evildoer. By this, you know what many people are upon; if they mention a scholar, emir, king, or others, they say: 'The late forgiven one' (*Al-Maghfur lahu*) or 'Dweller of Paradise'. Worse than that is their saying: 'Transferred to the Supreme Companion'. There is no doubt this is speaking about Allah without knowledge, and speaking about Allah without knowledge is equal to Shirk as the Almighty said {and that you associate with Allah that for which He has not sent down authority, and that you say about Allah that which you do not know} [Al-A'raf: 33]. As for the polytheist, we testify for him of the Fire because Allah said: {Indeed, he who associates others with Allah - Allah has forbidden him Paradise, and his refuge is the Fire. And there are not for the wrongdoers any helpers.} [Al-Ma'idah: 72]. (M) (N)
 b) He means, may Allah have mercy on him, except whom the Messenger, peace be upon him and his family, testified for of Paradise like the Ten and others, as will come at the end of his speech. Knowing that the creed of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah is to testify for believers and pious ones *in general* that they are people of Paradise, and that disbelievers, polytheists, and hypocrites are people of the Fire, as indicated by the noble verses and Mutawatir Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family. From that is His saying Glory be to Him: {Indeed, the righteous are in gardens and pleasure} [At-Tur: 17]. And His saying Mighty and Majestic: {Allah has promised the believing men and believing women gardens beneath which rivers flow, wherein they abide eternally} [At-Tawbah: 72] in many verses indicating this meaning. And His saying Glory be to Him regarding disbelievers: {And for those who disbelieve will be the fire of Hell. [Death] is not decreed for them so they may die, nor will its torment be lightened for them. Thus do We recompense every ungrateful one.} [Fatir: 36]. And His saying Glory be to Him: {Indeed, the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of the Fire - and never will you find for them a helper} [An-Nisa: 145] in other verses indicating this meaning. And Allah is the Guardian of success. (Z)

foot_note:

…. The Commentator said: The servant must be fearful and hopeful. Praiseworthy hope is the hope of a man who did an act of obedience to Allah upon light from Allah, so he hopes for His reward; or a man who committed a sin then repented from it to Allah, so he hopes for His forgiveness. …. He intends by this to refute the Khawarij and Mu'tazilah who said he exits Faith by committing a major sin. (M). …. This restriction is questionable. For the disbeliever enters Islam by the Two Testimonies if he does not pronounce them. If he pronounces them, he enters Islam by repentance from what necessitated his disbelief. He may exit Islam without
…. Denial (*Juhud*) for many reasons explained by scholars in the chapter of the Ruling of the Apostate. Among them is insulting Islam or the Prophet, peace be upon him and his family, or mocking Allah, His Messenger, His Book, or anything of His legislation Glory be to Him, due to His saying Glory be to Him: {Say, "Is it Allah and His verses and His Messenger that you were mocking?" * Make no excuse; you have disbelieved after your belief.} [At-Tawbah: 65-66]. Also among them is worshipping idols or statues, or calling upon the dead and seeking aid from them and asking them for support and help and the like, because this contradicts the statement 'La ilaha illa Allah', for it indicates that worship is the right of Allah alone. Among worship is Supplication, Seeking Aid, Bowing, Prostrating, Slaughtering, Vowing, etc. So whoever directs any of this to other than Allah, such as idols, statues, angels, Jinn, grave occupants, and other creatures, has associated partners with Allah and has not realized the statement 'La ilaha illa Allah'. These issues all expel one from Islam by consensus of scholars, and they are not issues of Denial (*Juhud*). Their evidences are known from the Book and Sunnah. There are many other issues by which a Muslim disbelieves not called Denial, mentioned by scholars in the chapter of the Ruling of the Apostate, so check them if you wish. And Allah is the Guardian of success. (Z)

text:
[Definition of Faith]
62- Faith (*Iman*) (1): is affirmation (*Iqrar*) with the tongue, and ratification (*Tasdiq*) with the heart (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. His saying: 'And Faith is affirmation with the tongue and ratification with the heart.' The author restricted it to these two pillars in defining Faith, which is the saying of the Murji'ah. Malik, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and all Ahl al-Hadith went to the view that it is ratification with the heart, affirmation with the tongue, and action with the limbs; it increases with obedience and decreases with disobedience. This is the truth and correctness. (M)
2. 
…. a) This definition has observation and deficiency. The correct view upon which Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah are is that Faith is speech, action, and belief; it increases with obedience and decreases with disobedience. Evidences for this from the Book and Sunnah are too many to count. The Commentator Ibn Abi al-Izz mentioned a group of them, so review them if you wish. Excluding action from Faith is the saying of the Murji'ah. The disagreement between them and Ahl al-Sunnah in this is not (merely) verbal, rather it is verbal and semantic, and many rulings result from it known to whoever contemplates the speech of Ahl al-Sunnah and the speech of the Murji'ah. And Allah is the One sought for help. (Z)
 b) This is the school of the Hanafis and Maturidis, contrary to the Salaf and the majority of Imams like Malik, Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, Al-Awza'i and others, for these added to Affirmation and Ratification: Action with the limbs. The difference between the two schools is not a formal (*Suri*) difference as the Commentator, may Allah have mercy on him, argued on the pretext that they all agreed that the committer of a major sin does not exit Faith, and that he is under Allah's will, if He wills He punishes him and if He wills He pardons him. For this agreement, even if correct, the Hanafis, if they were not opposing the majority a real opposition in denying that Action is part of Faith, would have agreed with them that Faith increases and decreases, and that its increase is by obedience and its decrease by disobedience, given the abundance of evidences from the Book, Sunnah, and Salafi traditions on that. The Commentator mentioned a good group of them (342-344). But the Hanafis insisted on speaking contrary to those explicit evidences regarding increase and decrease, and burdened themselves in interpreting them with apparent, nay false, affectation. The Commentator (p. 342) mentioned a sample of that; indeed he recounted from Abu al-Mu'in al-Nasafi that he impugned the authenticity of the Hadith ((Faith is seventy-odd branches...))

This is only because it is explicit in contradicting their school! Then how can the mentioned difference be formal, when they allow the most dissolute of them to say: My faith is like the faith of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq! Nay, like the faith of Prophets and Messengers and Gabriel and Michael, peace be upon them! How, when based on this school of theirs, they do not allow one of them—no matter how dissolute and immoral—to say: 'I am a believer, if Allah wills' (*Insha'Allah*), but rather he says: 'I am a believer truly!'? While Allah Almighty says: {The believers are only those who, when Allah is mentioned, their hearts become fearful, and when His verses are recited to them, it increases them in faith; and upon their Lord they rely * Who establish prayer and spend from what We have provided them * Those are the believers, truly.} [Al-Anfal: 2-4] {And who is more truthful than Allah in statement.} [An-Nisa: 22]. Based on all that, they went to extremes in their partisanship, mentioning that whoever makes an exception (*Istithna* - saying Insha'Allah) in his faith has disbelieved! They branched from it that it is not permissible for a Hanafi to marry a Shafi'i woman! Some of them were lenient—they claimed—and allowed that without the reverse, justifying it by saying: Treating her like the People of the Book! foot_note:

There is observation in that, for the Prophet, peace be upon him, informed that: ((Whoever has an atom's weight of faith in his heart will exit the Fire)) and did not restrict his Ummah with that, but mentioned faith absolutely. Many Hadiths indicating the existence of Paradise and Hell have been reported, as in the Eclipse Prayer Hadith where the Prophet, peace be upon him, explicitly mentioned seeing Paradise and Hell. Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah agreed that Paradise does not perish or cease to exist due to His saying Almighty {Its fruit is lasting and its shade} and His saying: {a gift without interruption} and other evidences. As for the Fire, it is likewise according to the majority of the Salaf; it does not perish or cease to exist, nor does anyone of its people exit it, as the Almighty said: {And they are not to emerge from the Fire}. Rather, the people of Paradise and the people of Fire are eternal in them as came in the authentic Hadith: ((O people of Paradise, eternity and no death; O people of Fire, eternity and no death)). It has been reported from some past scholars the saying of the perishing of the Fire, and this was attributed to Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, but it is not established from him. Likewise, his student Ibn al-Qayyim elaborated on this issue in his book Shifa' al-Alil and Hadi al-Arwah, but he
…. did not assert the perishing of the Fire. Rather he said, after mentioning more than twenty proofs for that: If it is asked: where did your foot end in this great issue? It is said: To His saying Almighty {Indeed, your Lord is an effecter of what He intends}. But he declared in the book Al-Wabil al-Sayyib that Paradise and Hell do not perish, and that the fire that perishes is the fire of the disobedient monotheists. Caution: Ibn al-Qayyim cited in Shifa' al-Alil and Hadi al-Arwah His saying Almighty {And they will not be removed from it} regarding the people of Fire, but the correct view is that it was said regarding the people of Paradise, so memorize this. Then know that the intent of Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah in mentioning the creation of Paradise and Hell and their non-perishing is to refute Jahm and his followers who oppose the texts of the Book and Sunnah with their false opinions and corrupt beliefs. Ibn al-Qayyim and others from Ahl al-Sunnah undertook recounting their sayings and refuting them, supporting the Sunnah and defending it. Jahm only took this grave path to be consistent with his proof, which is the proof =
…. called 'Proof of Occurrences' (*Dalil al-Akwan*), as its basis is cutting off infinite regress (*Tasalsul*), which is preventing events that have no beginning; so likewise events that have no end must be prevented. The refutation of him is detailed in Al-Nuniyyah. Ibn al-Qayyim recounted Jahm's saying on the perishing of Paradise and Hell and refuted him in verses, including:
He ruled that the Fire was not created nor Gardens of Eden
Rather they are two non-existents
So if they are created for the day of our return
Then they are, over times, perishing
And Al-Allaf (Mu'tazili) was subtle among his followers
So he came with the laugh of an ignorant jester
He said perishing happens in movements
Not in essence; wonder at this delirium (M)

text: 85- The Capacity (*Istita'ah*) by which action becomes obligatory, which is like success (*Tawfiq*) that cannot be attributed to the creature (as a permanent trait), is with the action. As for the Capacity from the aspect of health, ability (*Wus'*), possibility (*Tamakkun*), and soundness of instruments, it is before the action, and the address (of command/prohibition) relates to it. It is as the Almighty said: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} (1) [Al-Baqarah: 286].
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. The first (capacity with action) was held by the Ash'aris, and the other (capacity before action) was held by the Mu'tazilah. The correct view is asserting both together according to the detail mentioned by the author, may Allah have mercy on him. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah, may Allah have mercy on him, clarified that with a healing clarification; there is no harm in quoting it entirely for its importance. He said, may Allah's mercy be upon him, in ((Majmoo' al-Fatawa)) (8/371-376): ((People from our companions and others have spoken regarding the ((servant's capacity)): is it with his action or before it? They made them two contradictory sayings. A group made capacity with the action only. This is predominant among the Affirmers of Destiny, the Theologians from the companions of Al-Ash'ari and those who agreed with them from our companions and others. A group made capacity before the action, which is predominant among the Deniers (of Destiny) from the Mu'tazilah and Shia. The first group made power valid only for one action, as it accompanies it and does not separate from it. The others made capacity valid only for opposites, never accompanying the action. The Qadariyyah are more deviant, for they prevent power being with the action at all; according to them, the influencer must precede the effect and never accompany it, whether power, will, or command.
…. The truth indicated by the Book and Sunnah is that Capacity precedes the action and accompanies it as well, and another capacity accompanies it which is not valid for anything else. Capacity is of two types: Preceding valid for opposites, and Accompanying which is only with the action. The former is the correcting/enabling one for the action, making it possible; the latter is the obligating one for the action, realizing it. Allah Almighty said regarding the first: {And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way} [Al Imran: 97]. If this capacity were only with the action, Hajj would not be obligatory except on the one who performed Hajj, and no one would disobey by abandoning Hajj, nor would Hajj be obligatory on anyone before entering Ihram: nay, before finishing it! And the Almighty said: {So fear Allah as much as you are able} [At-Taghabun: 16]. He commanded fear according to ability; if He meant accompanying capacity, fear would not be obligatory on anyone except what he did only, since that is what that capacity accompanied. And the Almighty said: {Allah does not charge a soul except [with that within] its capacity} =
…. [Al-Baqarah: 286]. *Wus'* (Capacity) is the scope, what it contains and can bear. If accompanying capacity were meant, no one would be tasked except with the action he performed only, excluding the obligations he abandoned. 
…. Analogues to this are numerous. Every command in the Book and Sunnah whose obligation is suspended on capacity and lack thereof on lack of capacity does not mean accompanying capacity; otherwise, Allah would have only obligated duties on those who did them, and dropped them from those who didn't, so no one would sin by leaving the mentioned duty! As for the accompanying obligating capacity, it is like His saying Almighty: {They were not able to hear and they used to not see} [Hud: 20]. This capacity is the accompanying obligating one, since the other is necessary for obligation. The first is the Legal (*Shar'iyyah*) which is the basis of command and prohibition, reward and punishment; jurists speak of it, and it is dominant in people's custom. The second: is the Universal (*Kawniyyah*) which is the basis of Decree and Destiny; by it existence of the action is realized. The first is for Legal Command Words. The second is for Creative Universal Words, as He said: {and she believed in the words of her Lord and His scriptures} [At-Tahrim: 12]. People differed regarding the servant's power to do other than what the Truth knew or willed. The verification is that he may be capable by the first Legal Power preceding the action, for Allah is also capable of other than the Known and Willed, otherwise He would not be capable except of what He did. But the servant is not capable of that by the Power accompanying the action; for nothing exists except what Allah knew would exist and willed its existence, for what Allah willed happened, and what He did not will did not happen. Likewise the saying of the Disciples: {Can your Lord send down to us a table from the heaven?} [Al-Ma'idah: 112]; they only asked about this power. Likewise Jonah thought {that We would not decree [an extent] for him} [Al-Anbiya: 87] i.e., interpreted as power (*Qudrah*), as one says to a man: Can you do such? Meaning will you do it? This is famous in people's speech. When the Qadariyyah believed that the first (capacity before action) is sufficient for the occurrence of the action, and that the servant originates his will, they made him independent of Allah during the action! Just as the Jabriyyah, when they believed that the second is obligating for the action, and it is from other than him, saw him forced upon the action. Both are ugly errors. For the servant has a will which is subordinate to Allah's will as Allah mentioned in several places in His Book. If Allah made the servant willing, choosing, intending, it is impossible to say: He is forced and coerced, while He made him willing. It is impossible that he (the servant) originated =
…. the will for himself. If it is said: He is forced to choose, compelled to will, this has no parallel, and is not the concept of compulsion by necessity, and none is capable of that except Allah. Therefore, the Qadariyyah and Jabriyyah separated into two contradictory extremes, and both are correct in what they affirmed but not in what they denied. Ibn al-Khatib and similar Jabriyyah claim that knowledge of the need for a preponderator other than the servant for the servant's action to occur over its omission is necessary, because the possible with equal sides does not preponderate one side over the other except by a preponderator. Both sayings are correct, but the claim that one necessitates negating the other is not correct. For the servant is the originator of his actions, earner of them, and this origination needs an originator. So the servant is a doer, maker, originator; and being a doer, maker, originator after not being so necessitates a Maker for him, as He said: {For whoever wills among you to take a right course} [At-Takwir: 28], so if he wills rectitude he becomes rectified, then He said: {And you do not will except that Allah wills - Lord of the worlds} [At-Takwir: 29]. So what is known by necessity and what auditory and rational evidences indicated is all truth. That is why there is no might nor power except by Allah. The servant is poor to Allah, a poverty essential to him in his essence, attributes, and actions, even though he has an essence, attributes, and actions. So negating his actions is like negating his attributes and essence; it is denial of the truth, resembling the extremism of the extreme Sufis who make him (the servant) the Truth (God), and making anything of him independent of Allah or existing without Him is denial of the truth resembling the extremism of the one who said: {I am your most high lord} [An-Nazi'at: 24] and said he created himself. The truth is only what Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah are upon)). (N)

…. This is incorrect.  b) Meaning: nor can they bear except what He enabled them to do. This 'bearing' is what is like success (*Tawfiq*), not that which is of health, ability, possibility, and soundness of instruments. But He, Glory be to Him, wants ease and lightening for His servants, as the Almighty said: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship} [Al-Baqarah: 185]. If He increased what He tasked us with, we would bear it, but He favored us, had mercy on us, lightened for us, and did not place hardship on us in religion. This problem is answered by what preceded: that the intent is the capacity which is like success, not from the aspect of possibility and soundness of instruments. There is awkwardness in the phrase, so reflect on it)). (N)

text:
[The Religion with Allah is Islam]
103- The religion of Allah in the earth and the heaven is one, and it is the religion of Islam. Allah Almighty said: {Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam} [Al Imran: 19]. And He said: {and have approved for you Islam as religion} [Al-Ma'idah: 3] (1).

[The Middle Path of Religion]
104- It is between excess and negligence, between likening (*Tashbih*) and negation (*Ta'til*), between fatalism (*Jabr*) and denial of destiny (*Qadar*), and between security (*Amn*) and despair (*Iyas*).

[This is our Religion]
105- This is our religion and our belief, outwardly and inwardly. We are free before Allah Almighty from everyone who opposes what we have mentioned and clarified.
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. The Commentator, may Allah have mercy on him, said: The religion of Islam is what Allah Glory be to Him legislated for His servants on the tongues of His Messengers. The origin of this religion and its branches is its narration from the Messengers. It is apparent with utmost clarity. Every discerner, small or big, eloquent or non-Arab, smart or dull, can enter it in the shortest time. And exiting from it happens even faster than that, by denying a word, belying, opposing, lying against Allah, doubting the word of Allah Almighty, rejecting what He revealed, doubting what Allah negated doubt about, or other things of similar meaning. The Book and Sunnah indicated the clarity of the religion of Islam, ease of learning it, and that a delegate learns it then leaves in his time. The Prophet's teaching, peace be upon him, varied in some wordings according to the learner. If he was from a far land, like Dimam bin Tha'labah al-Najdi and the delegation of Abdul Qais, he taught them what they could not be ignorant of, ==
…. knowing that his religion would spread in the horizons, and he would send to them those who teach them Fiqh in all they need. Whoever was from a nearby land could come every time, so he learns gradually—or if he knew he already knew the essentials—he answered him according to his state and need, as indicated by the context of the questioner, like his saying: ((Say I believe in Allah then stand firm)). As for one who legislates a religion Allah did not permit, it is known that its principles necessitating it cannot be narrated from the Prophet, peace be upon him, nor from other Messengers, for it is false, and the requirement of falsehood is false, just as the requirement of truth is truth. (N)

text:
[Deviant Sects]
We ask Allah Almighty to make us firm on Faith, seal our lives with it, and protect us from conflicting desires, scattered opinions, and vile sects (1), such as: The Anthropomorphists (*Mushabbihah*), Mu'tazilah, Jahmiyyah, Jabriyyah, Qadariyyah, and others (2)
foot_note:
1. (1) 
…. Every sect opposing what Ahl al-Sunnah wal-Jama'ah are upon is a vile, false sect. Allah refuted the Mushabbihah and the negationist Jahmiyyah by His saying: {There is nothing like unto Him, and He is the Hearing, the Seeing}. The Anthropomorphist worships an idol, the Negator worships nothingness, and the Affirmer worships One Lord, Unique, Eternal Refuge. How excellent is the saying of Ibn al-Qayyim in Al-Nuniyyah:
We do not liken His description to our attributes
Indeed, the Anthropomorphist is an idol worshipper
Nay, nor do we empty Him of His attributes
Indeed, the Negator is a worshipper of falsehood
Then know that the Jahmiyyah are deniers of Attributes; Jabriyyah are those who said the servant has no optional action; Qadariyyah are those who said servants create their actions; Rafidah are those who declared Companions disbelievers and took the path of Jahmiyyah in denying Attributes. All these sects are sects of deviation and misguidance. Jahm is the one who innovated Negation, Jabr (Fatalism), and Irja' as narrated in Al-Nuniyyah. If anything of it is attributed to others, it is because they supported and backed it. How excellent is what was said:
You oppose people in what they saw and narrated
And all of them claim winning the victory
So take a saying supported by the text
Either from Allah or from the Master of Mankind (M)
2. 
…. Such as the Blind Imitators (*Muqallidah*) who made imitation (*Taqlid*) an obligatory religion upon everyone who came after the fourth century AH, and due to that turned away from being guided by the light of the Book and Sunnah. They accused everyone who tried to escape sectarian stagnation towards adhering to the guidance of the Prophet, peace be upon him, with whatever their desires dictated. May Allah have mercy on the Imam of Sunnah where he says:
The religion of the Prophet Muhammad is reports (*Akhbar*)
Yes, the mount for the young man is traditions (*Athar*)
.........Do not turn away from Hadith and its people
..................For Opinion is night and Hadith is day
Perhaps a young man is ignorant of the trace of guidance
While the sun is rising having lights (N)
